text:
PAIGE COHEN: Now that so many
of us are working from home,

we're communicating
virtually a lot more,

and it can be really easy
to send the wrong message,

hit the wrong tone,
or just say something

where you accidentally
offend someone through text.

So I have a few
tips for you that

can help you figure out how to
just hit the right tone when

you're communicating digitally
with your team members
or just people in general.

Important to remember that
typos really send a message.

Any emotional state
that you're in,

typos can make it seem like,
for example, if you're angry,
that you're even more angry.

If you're in a rush, people
are going to read the email

and see a typo and kind of
assume that you don't really

have the time to respond
to them thoughtfully.

Read the message out
loud before you send it.

It'll help you catch any
errors that might be in it.

Punctuation actually
really matters, especially
with short sentences or phrases.

It gives things kind
of a finality that

can come off as negative
when you put a period
on the end of short phrases.

So for example, typing
OK to someone versus OK,

period, the second
one can come off

as a little bit abrupt
and may make people
think you're upset with them.

I know it sounds silly and
maybe even unprofessional,

but emojis, used
with caution, can

be really helpful in
clarifying your message.

People can't see your face
when you're talking to them,

so adding a happy face every
once in a while kind of just

makes the message feel lighter
and helps express your tone.

Slack as a platform is generally
kind of urgent seeming.

When people get a
message from you,

they often think they have
to respond right away.

It's just like getting an AIM
if you grew up in the '90s

and you know what
I'm talking about.

But a better way
to Slack someone

is basically just to
give them a time frame.

So if it's not timely,
just say, hey, no rush.
I have a quick question.

If it is timely, you
might want to say,

I need this by end of
day or by this afternoon.

That might seem kind of
obvious, but a lot of the time,
we forget to do those things.

And lastly, I know I personally
need to work on this.

When you see someone has the
"do not disturb" message on,

those little Zs by their
name, try to respect it,

even if you're anxious about
getting your project done.

You're going to end up having a
better relationship with people

when you respect their space
when they need to take it.

Finally, if someone sends
you an email or Slack

message that upsets you, it's
best to just wait to respond.

Once you have a little
time to just think

through your
thoughts, you're going

to be able to respond with
a little bit more clarity
and with more calm.

If you have any
more tips for us,

things you do to make sure
your communication is on point,

just leave it for
us in the comments,
share it with each other.

We're all going to be
better communicators for it.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
